editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.head: ACT For a new Leavie of Horse to be put out by the Shires. And List of the Colonels and their inferiour Officers, with their severall numbers of Horse.
div.p:
THE Committee of Estates according to the trust and power committed to them, Taking to consideration how necessar it is; That when the Prince his Highnesse shall come into this Kingdom, His Person be attended with all honour and respect. And considering the danger our Borders are in of ane invasion from the Sectaries and their adherents in England, who have presently considerable numbers of forces in the North. And may upon a sudden invade this Kingdom, to the disturbance of the Peace thereof, and the prejudice of the present undertakings of this Kingdome, in pursuance of the ends of the Solemn League and Covenant, Have thought fit for the reasons foresaids, to appoint the just equall half of the last proportion of Horse, to be presently levied forth of the severall Shires of this Kingdom. And for that effect Ordains the Committee of War of the severall Shires, to cause the Heritors, proper Woodsetters, Life-renters, and others subject
in our-putting of Horses, conform to the List hereto subjoyned, put out their Horse and Men, well armed with sufficient Pistols and Swords. And that the Heretors, Life renters, and others foresaids of the severall Shires who are lyable to put out Horse, be ordained to bring their severall proportions armed and provided as aforesaid, to the place of Randevouse in each Shire, under the pain of 400. merks for each deficient Horseman, which are hereby ordained to be kept at the diets following, viz. All the Shires on this side of Spey upon the 15 day of August next. And these benorth Spey upon the 22. day of the same moneth. And Ordains the saids Colonels and Committees in every Shire to have their proportions of Horse armed and provided as aforesaid, at the place of Randevouse, and at the diets respective abovementioned, to march according to such orders as shall be then sent to them, under the penaltie aforesaid. And for the more speedy and effectuall raising of the said Horse, The Committee gives power and command to the Colonells, with the assistance of such of the Committee of the Shire as will joyne with them: and are hereby commanded to be assisting to them to poynd and distreinÊ’ie the goods of any Heretors and others foresaids, who are deficient in putting out of their said Horse for the foresaid penaltie of 400. merks for each Horseman wanting at the day of Randevouse, from every Heretor and others foresaids. And farther the saids Committee declares, that the Heretors and others foresaids, failing in their proportions, shall be esteemed as enemies to, and hinderers of the publick service of the Kingdom, in pursuance of the ends of the Covenant, and disaffected persons to the preservation of Religion, of the Prince his Highnes Person, the safety of the Kingdome. And the Committee of Estates Ordains the foresaids Committees to use all diligence for performing the foresaids duties
intrusted to them, as they will testifie their affection to Religion, the peace of the Kingdom, and the preservation of the Prince his Highnesse Person. And that they fail not to make report to the Committee of Estates of this Kingdome within six dayes after the dayes of Randevouse respectivÃ¨ above written assigned to the Committees of the Shires respective as is aforesaid. And if the Committees of the Shires be remisse in their meetings, or in putting their orders to execution, that the Colonels with such of the Committee as are willing to joyn with them, conveen upon al occasions for putting their orders to execution, and for doing every thing that may further this present Levie, being alwayes comptable for their proceedings to the Committee of Estates. And if any person or persons, of what degree, qualitie or condition soever, shall offer to oppose or obstruct by violence the resolution of the Committee of Estates, with power to the saids Committees and Colonels, to use all meanes to compose them, and if need be, to pursue the raisers of the tumults, and the publick opposers of the resolutions of the Committee in a hostile way by the strength of the Shire: And if the insurrection or opposition come to that height, that the Shire where it falls out is not able to suppresse the same, That the Committees, Colonels and Commanders of the next adjacent Shires on all quarters, joyn for suppressing thereof, as they shall receive advertisement. And that the saids Forces may be kept in the better order and discipline, The said Committee ordains all Officers constantly to attend their charge, and that none of them upon any pretext whatsoever, be absent the space of three dayes, without waarrand. With certification to the contraveeners hereof, that their places shall be declared vacand, and another established in their charge. And the Committee of Estates declares, that whatsoever Officer or Souldier shall be found guiltie of taking at
their own hand, horse, or any other goods from the subjects of this Kingdome, that he shall die for the same. And for the better regulating and putting forth of the said Horse of such as will not fail to put out a whole horse, It is declared, that the greatest rent of these to be joyned for making up of horse, shall provide the horse and man; and the rest to joyne and contribute according to 160 l. for ilk horseman. And where the rent is equall, to cast lots.

div.head: Follows the List of the Horse to be put out of the severall Shires, with the names of the Colonels and Rutmasters, and their divisions.
div.p:
Out of the Sheriffdom of Roxburgh and Selkirk 100 horse; out of the Sheriffdom of Berwick 50 horse; out of the Sherifdom of Hadintoun 50 horses; out of the Sheriffdom of Edinburgh 50 horses; Out of the Sheriffdom of Lithgow 30. Out of the Sheriffdom of Peebles 20. Out of the Sheriffdome of Dumfreis 60. Out of the sheriffd. of Wigtoun and Kirkcudbright 60. Out of the sheriffd. of Air and Renfrew 120. Out of the sheriffd. of Lanerick 100. Out of the sheriffd. of Stirline and Clackmannan 60. Out of the sheriffd. of Fyfe and Kinrocher 120. Out of the sheriffd. of Perth 120. Out of the sheriffd. of Forfar 70. Out of the sheriffd. of Kincardyne 27. Out of the sheriffd. of Aberdeen 116. Out of the sheriffd. of Bamf 26. Out of the sheriffd. of Elgine and Nairn, & that part of Innernes on this side of Ness 60. Out of the Earl of Seafort and Lord Lovats division of Innernes 60. Out of the E. of Seaforts part of Innernes, Caithnes and Sutherland 60. to be divided according to the act of Parl. thereanent. Out of the sheriffd. of Dumbartane 10. Which number of horse above-written are to be divided in three Regiments.
